case_name: Messrs. Baburally Sardar & Abdul Razzak v. Corporation of Calcutta

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 177 of 1963 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 177 of 1963. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: The appeal is from the judgment and order dated May 14, 1963 of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 380 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated May 14, 1963 of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 380 of 1962.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court set aside the acquittal of Ms. Baburally Sardar of Steward Hogg Market, Calcutta (appellant number 1) and Abdul Razzak, a partner of that firm (appellant number 2).

anchor.surface_text: ment of the High Court of Calcutta setting aside the acquittal of M s. Baburally Sardar of Steward Hogg Market, Calcutta, appellant number 1 and of Abdul Razzak, a partner of that firm, appellant number 2,

facts.text: Offence under s.16(1)(a)(i) of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954 read with s.7(1) of that Act.

anchor.surface_text: in respect of an offence under s. 16  1   a   i  of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954 read with S. 7  1  of that act.

facts.text: The facts stated are not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The facts which are number in dispute are briefly these

facts.text: On June 1, 1960 a Food Inspector of the Corporation of Calcutta visited the shop of the appellants. Abdul Razzak was in charge.

anchor.surface_text: On June 1, 1960 a Food Inspector of the Corporation of Calcutta visited the shop of the appellants. At that time Abdul Razzak was in charge.

facts.text: Food Inspector took samples of Comela Brand condensed milk from the shop, one sent to the Public Analyst.

anchor.surface_text: He took samples of Comela Brand companydensed milk from the shop, one of which was sent to the Public Analyst.

facts.text: Public Analyst found the milk fat content of the condensed milk to be 3.4%, which did not conform to the prescribed standard.

anchor.surface_text: Upon an analysis made by the Public Analyst the milk fat companytent of the companydensed milk was found to be 3.4 which did number companyform to the prescribed standard in respect of companydensed milk.

facts.text: A complaint was lodged against the firm before the Municipal Magistrate and Additional Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta. Apart from the firm, five other persons including Abdul Razzak were named as accused.

anchor.surface_text: A companyplaint was thereupon lodged against the firm before the Municipal Magistrate and Additional Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta. Apart from the firm five other persons, including Abdul Razzak were also named as accused persons.

facts.text: One accused, Mohd. Yasin, did not appear; it was represented he was not mentally fit, so counsel for Corporation gave him up.

anchor.surface_text: One of the accused persons, Mohd. Yasin did number appear but it was represented to the learned Magistrate that the person was number mentally fit. Thereupon the companynsel for the Corporation gave him up.

facts.text: Other accused persons pleaded not guilty and were acquitted by the Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: The other accused persons pleaded number guilty and were eventually acquitted by the Magistrate.

facts.text: Appeal preferred before High Court under s.417 CrPC against Magistrate's order; High Court allowed appeal only against the appellants, dismissed against others.

anchor.surface_text: Against that order an appeal was preferred before the High Court under s. 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. The High Court, however, allowed the appeal only against the appellants but dismissed it against the remaining accused persons.

facts.text: Appellants' defence: Tins of condensed milk purchased by the firm on May 3, 1960 from Messrs S. Choudhury Brothers under document Ex. A.

anchor.surface_text: The tins of companydensed milk were purchased by the firm on May 3, 1960 from Messrs S. Choudhury Brothers under a document of sale Ex. A.

facts.text: Firm demanded warranty from Messrs. Choudhury Brothers but they did not furnish written guarantee, stating certificate and warranty on each tin.

anchor.surface_text: At that time the firm had demanded a warranty from the traders, that is, Messrs. Choudhury Brothers, but they did number furnish a written guarantee on the ground that a certificate and a warranty had been given on each tin of companydensed milk.

facts.text: Appellants pleaded tins were in the same condition as purchased and had no reason to believe alteration in nature, substance or quality.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants further pleaded that the tins were in the same companydition in which they were when they were purchased from Messrs Choudhury Brothers and that they had numberreason to believe that there was any alteration in their nature, substance or quality subsequent to the purchase of the tins.

facts.text: Attempt made to secure appearance of S. Choudhury of Messrs. Choudhury Brothers but failed as he could not be traced at the address in cash memo.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that an attempt was made to secure the appearance of S. Choudhury of Messrs. Choudhury Brothers, but it failed because he companyld number be traced at the address given in the cash memo.

facts.text: Public Analyst found fat content 3.4% whereas minimum prescribed is 9% for condensed milk.

anchor.surface_text: As already stated, the Public Analyst found that the fat companytent of the companydensed milk was only 3.4 whereas the minimum prescribed in the Appendix is 9.

facts.text: Condensed milk stored by appellants for sale was adulterated, breaching s.16(1)(a)(i).

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, clear that the companydensed milk stored by the appellants for sale was adulterated and, therefore, there was a breach of the provisions of S. 16  1   a   i  of the Act.

facts.text: No warranty in prescribed form obtained by appellants.

anchor.surface_text: Nor again, had the appellant obtained a warranty in the prescribed form.

facts.text: Label on tins: 'Comela-Full Cream sweetened condensed milk made on formula of Holland Product. Comela BrandThe contents of the tin are scientifically preserved, pure and produced from healthy Cows milk. ...'

anchor.surface_text: The contents of the label upon which reliance is placed by him are as follows Comela-Full Cream sweetened companydensed milk made on formula of Holland Product. Comela BrandThe companytents of the tin are scientifically preserved, pure and produced from healthy Cows milk. Comela full cream companydensed milk easily digestable and are ideal food for babies. Special care is taken to maintain freshness- Prepared by Kwality Diary.

facts.text: High Court convicted appellants under s.16(1)(a) and sentenced each to fine of Rs. 2,000.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, therefore, the High Court was right in setting aside the acquittal of the appellants and companyvicting them of the offence under S. 1 6  1   a  of the Act and sentencing them to pay fine of Rs. 2,000 each.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is without merit and is dismissed.

issues.text: Whether the condensed milk stored by the appellants for sale was adulterated under Section 2(i) of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act read with the prescribed standards?

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 i  defines the word adulterated. According to the definition an article of food shall be deemed to be adulterated in various circumstances, one of which is where the quality or purity of the article falls below the pres- cribed standard. In the Act prescribed means prescribed by the rules. Rule 5 of the Rules

issues.text: Whether the appellants could avail the defence under Section 19(2) of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act?

anchor.surface_text: based upon s. 19 2  of the Act and was briefly this The tins of companydensed milk were purchased by the firm on May 3, 1960 from Messrs S. Choudhury Brothers under a document of sale Ex. A. At that time the firm had demanded a warranty from the traders, that is, Messrs. Choudhury Brothers, but they did number furnish a written guarantee on the ground that a certificate and a warranty had been given on each tin of companydensed milk.

issues.text: Whether the label on the tins or the cash memo constituted a warranty in the prescribed form or as per the proviso to Rule 12-A of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Rules?

anchor.surface_text: Nor again, had the appellant obtained a warranty in the prescribed form. Rule 12-A provides that every trader selling an article of food to a vendor shall deliver to the vendor a warranty in form 6-A, if required to do so by the vendor. No such warranty was demanded by the appellants, number given by Messrs. S. Chaudhury Brothers. No doubt, under the proviso to the aforesaid sub-rule numberwarranty in the prescribed form is necessary if the label on the article of food or cash memo delivered by the trader to the vendor in respect of that article companytains a warranty certifying that the food companytained in the companytainer or mentioned in the cash memo is the same in nature, substance and quality as demanded by the vendor.

issues.text: Whether the defence under Section 19(2) read with Rule 12-A and Form VI-A succeeds in the absence of a written warranty certifying the nature, substance and quality?

anchor.surface_text: The defence under s. 19 2  of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954 cannot succeed, as the appellants failed to prove that they purchased the articles of food with a written warranty in the prescribed form. The label on the tin companytainer gave a description of the article of food, but it did number give a warranty certifying that the food is the same in nature, substance and quality as demanded by the vendor.

arguments.claim: The appellants are entitled to the defence under Section 19(2) of the PFA Act as they purchased the tins of condensed milk from Messrs S. Choudhury Brothers under Ex. A, demanded warranty which was given via certificate on each tin, tins were in same condition, and had no reason to believe adulterated.

anchor.surface_text: based upon s. 19 2  of the Act and was briefly this The tins of companydensed milk were purchased by the firm on May 3, 1960 from Messrs S. Choudhury Brothers under a document of sale Ex. A. At that time the firm had demanded a warranty from the traders, that is, Messrs. Choudhury Brothers, but they did number furnish a written guarantee on the ground that a certificate and a warranty had been given on each tin of companydensed milk. The appellants further pleaded that the tins were in the same companydition in which they were when they were purchased from Messrs Choudhury Brothers and that they had numberreason to believe that there was any alteration in their nature, substance or quality subsequent to the purchase of the tins.

arguments.court_reasoning: No written warranty in prescribed form obtained; article did not conform to standards so not same in nature/substance/quality as demanded; ignorance not defence per s.19(1).

arguments.claim: The labels on the tins satisfy the requirements of the proviso to Rule 12-A as a warranty.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Das Gupta for the appellants, says that the labels on the tins satisfy the requirements of the proviso and faintly suggested that the cash memo also satisfies the companyditions. The companytents of the label upon which reliance is placed by him are as follows Comela-Full Cream sweetened companydensed milk made on formula of Holland Product. Comela BrandThe companytents of the tin are scientifically preserved, pure and produced from healthy Cows milk.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: abel companytains numberwarranty of the kind referred to in the proviso. Moreover, it is number even in the form given for a label prescribed for Swee

arguments.court_reasoning: Label contains no warranty certifying food is same in nature, substance and quality as demanded by vendor; not in prescribed form under r.42-B(b); 'Full cream' undefined and insufficient to verify standards.

arguments.claim: The cash memo satisfies the conditions of the proviso to Rule 12-A as a warranty.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Das Gupta for the appellants, says that the labels on the tins satisfy the requirements of the proviso and faintly suggested that the cash memo also satisfies the companyditions.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: panydensed milk of the prescribed nature, substance and quality. It may be that the appellants sold them in the same state as they purchased them. But

arguments.court_reasoning: Cash memo specifies only quantity, description, rate, amount; no warranty mentioned.

arguments.claim: The condensed milk was adulterated under s.2(i) as quality fell below prescribed standard (fat 3.4% vs 9%).

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 i  defines the word adulterated. According to the definition an article of food shall be deemed to be adulterated in various circumstances, one of which is where the quality or purity of the article falls below the pres- cribed standard. In the Act prescribed means prescribed by the rules. Rule 5 of the Rules framed by the Central Government under s. 23 1  of the Act read with s. 4 2  thereof runs thus Standards of quality

arguments.claim: Storing the adulterated condensed milk for sale contravenes s.16(1)(a)(i) PFA.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, clear that the companydensed milk stored by the appellants for sale was adulterated and, therefore, there was a breach of the provisions of S. 16 1  a   i  of the Act.

arguments.claim: Ignorance of nature, substance or quality is no defence per s.19(1).

anchor.surface_text: In view of the provisions of S. 19 1  it was number open to the appellants to companytend that they were ignorant of the nature, substance and quality of the companydensed milk sold by them.

arguments.claim: s.19(2) defence requires proof of purchase as same in nature/substance/quality with written warranty in prescribed form certifying that, sold in same state, no reason to believe otherwise, and notice given.

anchor.surface_text: Subsection  2  of S. 19, however, furnishes a defence to a vendor ignorant of the nature, substance and quality of food sold by him provided he satisfies the requirements of that provision. Omitting the second proviso thereto, which is number relevant in the present case, sub-s.  2  of S. 19 reads thus A vendor shall number be deemed to have companymitted an offence if he proves- i  that the article of food was purchased by him as the same in nature, substance and quality as that demanded by the purchaser and with a written warranty in the prescribed form, if any, to the effect that it was of such nature, substance and quality that he had numberreason to believe at the time when he sold it that the food was number of such nature, substance and quality and that he sold it in the same state as he purchased it Provided that such a defence shall be open to the vendor only if he has submitted to the food inspector or the local authority a companyy of the warranty with a written numberice stating that he intends to rely on it and specifying the name and address of the person from whom he received it, and has also sent a like numberice of his intention to that person.

arguments.claim: The article was not the same in nature, substance and quality as demanded (condensed milk per standards) since it failed analysis.

anchor.surface_text: The aforesaid defence was available to the appellants provided that they showed, in the first place, that what was stored by them for sale to purchasers demanding companydensed milk was in fact milk which had been companycentrated from full cream milk so as to companyform to the standard of quality given in A. 1 1.07 of Appendix B. For, it would be milk which satisfies the standard prescribed therein which can be regarded as companydensed milk under the Act. Upon analysis, however, it was found that the so-called companydensed milk companytained in the samples taken by the Food Inspector from the appellants was far inferior to that prescribed for companydensed milk. It companyld, therefore, number be regarded as the same in nature, substance and quality as that demanded by the purchaser.

arguments.claim: No warranty in prescribed form obtained; Rule 12-A requires Form VI-A if demanded (not demanded here), but proviso requires label/cash memo to certify same as demanded by vendor.

anchor.surface_text: Nor again, had the appellant obtained a warranty in the prescribed form. Rule 12-A provides that every trader selling an article of food to a vendor shall deliver to the vendor a warranty in form 6-A, if required to do so by the vendor. No such warranty was demanded by the appellants, number given by Messrs. S. Chaudhury Brothers. No doubt, under the proviso to the aforesaid sub-rule numberwarranty in the prescribed form is necessary if the label on the article of food or cash memo delivered by the trader to the vendor in respect of that article companytains a warranty certifying that the food companytained in the companytainer or mentioned in the cash memo is the same in nature, substance and quality as demanded by the vendor.

arguments.claim: The label does not contain a warranty of the kind in the proviso to r.12-A.

anchor.surface_text: This label companytains numberwarranty of the kind referred to in the proviso. Moreover, it is number even in the form given for a label prescribed for Sweetened companydensed milk. Under r. 42-B b  the label prescribed is as follows CONDENSED FULL CREAM MILK  Sweetened  This tin companytains the equivalent of litres of milk with sugar added.

arguments.claim: 'Full cream' is undefined; without quantity, cannot verify compliance with milk solids/fat standards.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Das Gupta strongly relied upon the words Full Cream and said that where companydensed milk is said to have been obtained from full cream the requirements of law must be deemed to have been satisfied. For one thing Full cream has numberhere been defined in the Act or the rules. Moreover, without knowing the quantity of Full cream which was companydensed in the milk companytained in each tin it is impossible even to calculate the quantity of milk solids and fat in each tin.

arguments.claim: Accepting tins labelled as such, vendor had reason to believe not proper condensed milk.

anchor.surface_text: The label, therefore, is of little assistance to the appellants. Moreover, when a vendor accepts from the trader tins purported to be of companydensed milk bearing a label of this kind he cannot be said to have had numberreason to believe that it was number companydensed milk of the prescribed nature, substance and quality.

As for the so-called cash memo it is sufficient to point out that all that it specifies is Quantity Description Rate Per Amount 1 C C Comela Milk C 70/-Case Rs. 70 00 There is number a whisper of any warranty on it.

arguments.claim: High Court correctly set aside acquittal and convicted under s.16(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, therefore, the High Court was right in setting aside the acquittal of the appellants and companyvicting them of the offence under S. 1 6  1   a  of the Act and sentencing them to pay fine of Rs. 2,000 each.

arguments.claim: Defence under s.19(2) fails for lack of proof of written warranty in prescribed form; label is mere description, not warranty certifying same as demanded.

anchor.surface_text: The defence under s. 19 2  of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954 cannot succeed, as the appellants failed to prove that they purchased the articles of food with a written warranty in the prescribed form. The label on the tin companytainer gave a description of the article of food, but it did number give a warranty certifying that the food is the same in nature, substance and quality as demanded by the vendor.

holdings.text: the condensed milk stored by the appellants for sale was adulterated and, therefore, there was a breach of the provisions of S. 16 1   a   i  of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, clear that the condensed milk stored by the appellants for sale was adulterated and, therefore, there was a breach of the provisions of S. 16  1   a   i  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Public Analyst found fat content 3.4% below prescribed minimum 9% per Appendix B A.11.07; s.2(i) deems such article adulterated; storing for sale breaches s.16(1)(a)(i).

holdings.text: In view of the provisions of S. 19 1  it was not open to the appellants to contend that they were ignorant of the nature, substance and quality of the condensed milk sold by them.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the provisions of S. 19 1  it was not open to the appellants to contend that they were ignorant of the nature, substance and quality of the condensed milk sold by them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.19(1) bars defence of ignorance unless s.19(2) requirements met.

holdings.text: the aforesaid defence was available to the appellants provided that they showed... that what was stored by them for sale to purchasers demanding condensed milk was in fact milk which had been concentrated from full cream milk so as to conform to the standard of quality given in A. 11.07 of Appendix B... Upon analysis, however, it was found that the so-called condensed milk contained in the samples taken by the Food Inspector from the appellants was far inferior to that prescribed for condensed milk. It could, therefore, not be regarded as the same in nature, substance and quality as that demanded by the purchaser.

anchor.surface_text: The aforesaid defence was available to the appellants provided that they showed, in the first place, that what was stored by them for sale to purchasers demanding condensed milk was in fact milk which had been concentrated from full cream milk so as to conform to the standard of quality given in A. 11.07 of Appendix B.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.19(2)(i) requires proof article purchased 'as the same in nature, substance and quality as that demanded'; analysis showed non-conformity to condensed milk standards, so not same as demanded.

holdings.text: Nor again, had the appellant obtained a warranty in the prescribed form.

anchor.surface_text: Nor again, had the appellant obtained a warranty in the prescribed form.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No demand or delivery of Form VI-A warranty per r.12-A; proviso not satisfied as label/cash memo lack required certification.

holdings.text: This label contains no warranty of the kind referred to in the proviso.

anchor.surface_text: This label contains no warranty of the kind referred to in the proviso. Moreover, it is not even in the form given for a label prescribed for Sweetened condensed milk. Under r. 42-B b  the label prescribed is as follows CONDENSED FULL CREAM MILK  Sweetened  This tin contains the equivalent of litres of milk with sugar added.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Label describes product but does not certify 'same in nature, substance and quality as demanded by the vendor' per r.12-A proviso; not in prescribed form r.42-B(b); 'full cream' undefined, lacks quantities to verify standards.

holdings.text: As for the so-called cash memo it is sufficient to point out that all that it specifies is Quantity Description Rate Per Amount 1 C C Comela Milk C 70/-Case Rs. 70 00 There is no a whisper of any warranty on it.

anchor.surface_text: As for the so-called cash memo it is sufficient to point out that all that it specifies is Quantity Description Rate Per Amount 1 C C Comela Milk C 70/-Case Rs. 70 00 There is no a whisper of any warranty on it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cash memo lists only quantity, description, rate, amount; no warranty certification per r.12-A proviso.

holdings.text: when a vendor accepts from the trader tins purported to be of condensed milk bearing a label of this kind he cannot be said to have had no reason to believe that it was not condensed milk of the prescribed nature, substance and quality.

anchor.surface_text: The label, therefore, is of little assistance to the appellants. Moreover, when a vendor accepts from the trader tins purported to be of condensed milk bearing a label of this kind he cannot be said to have had no reason to believe that it was not condensed milk of the prescribed nature, substance and quality.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.19(2) requires no reason to believe not of required nature etc.; inadequate label gives vendor reason to doubt compliance.

holdings.text: In the circumstances, therefore, the High Court was right in setting aside the acquittal of the appellants and convicting them of the offence under S. 16 1   a  of the Act and sentencing them to pay fine of Rs. 2,000 each.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, therefore, the High Court was right in setting aside the acquittal of the appellants and convicting them of the offence under S. 16  1   a  of the Act and sentencing them to pay fine of Rs. 2,000 each.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adulteration proved, s.19(2) defence fails; upholds High Court reversal of acquittal and conviction.

holdings.text: The defence under s. 19 2  of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954 cannot succeed, as the appellants failed to prove that they purchased the articles of food with a written warranty in the prescribed form. The label on the tin container gave a description of the article of food, but it did not give a warranty certifying that the food is the same in nature, substance and quality as demanded by the vendor.

anchor.surface_text: The defence under s. 19 2  of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954 cannot succeed, as the appellants failed to prove that they purchased the articles of food with a written warranty in the prescribed form. The label on the tin container gave a description of the article of food, but it did not give a warranty certifying that the food is the same in nature, substance and quality as demanded by the vendor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Separate concurrence: s.19(2) read with r.12-A and Form VI-A requires written warranty certifying nature/substance/quality as demanded; label mere description, insufficient.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, clear that the condensed milk stored by the appellants for sale was adulterated and, therefore, there was a breach of the provisions of S. 16  1   a   i  of the Act.

In the circumstances, therefore, the High Court was right in setting aside the acquittal of the appellants and convicting them of the offence under S. 1 6  1   a  of the Act and sentencing them to pay fine of Rs. 2,000 eac

anchor.surface_text: The aforesaid defence was available to the appellants provided that they showed, in the first place, that what was stored by them for sale to purchasers demanding condensed milk was in fact milk which had been concentrated from full cream milk so as to conform to the standard of quality given in A. 11.07 of Appendix B.

In the circumstances, therefore, the High Court was right in setting aside the acquittal of the appellants and convicting them of the offence under S. 1 6  1   a  of the Act and sentencing them to pay fine of Rs. 2,000 eac

anchor.surface_text: This label contains no warranty of the kind referred to in the proviso. Moreover, it is not even in the form given for a label prescribed for Sweetened condensed milk. Under r. 42-B b  the label prescribed is as follows CONDENSED FULL CREAM MILK  Sweetened  This tin contains the equivalent of litres of milk with sugar added.

In the circumstances, therefore, the High Court was right in setting aside the acquittal of the appellants and convicting them of the offence under S. 1 6  1   a  of the Act and sentencing them to pay fine of Rs. 2,000 eac

anchor.surface_text: As for the so-called cash memo it is sufficient to point out that all that it specifies is Quantity Description Rate Per Amount 1 C C Comela Milk C 70/-Case Rs. 70 00 There is no a whisper of any warranty on it.

In the circumstances, therefore, the High Court was right in setting aside the acquittal of the appellants and convicting them of the offence under S. 1 6  1   a  of the Act and sentencing them to pay fine of Rs. 2,000 eac

anchor.surface_text: The label, therefore, is of little assistance to the appellants. Moreover, when a vendor accepts from the trader tins purported to be of condensed milk bearing a label of this kind he cannot be said to have had no reason to believe that it was not condensed milk of the prescribed nature, substance and quality.

In the circumstances, therefore, the High Court was right in setting aside the acquittal of the appellants and convicting them of the offence under S. 1 6  1   a  of the Act and sentencing them to pay fine of Rs. 2,000 eac

edges.explanation: Identical span: holding h9 that defence cannot succeed directly addresses i4

anchor.surface_text: The defence under s. 19 2  of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954 cannot succeed, as the appellants failed to prove that they purchased the articles of food with a written warranty in the prescribed form. The label on the tin container gave a description of the article of food, but it did not give a warranty certifying that the food is the same in nature, substance and quality as demanded by the vendor.

In the circumstances, therefore, the High Court was right in setting aside the acquittal of the appellants and convicting them of the offence under S. 1 6  1   a  of the Act and sentencing them to pay fine of Rs. 2,000 eac
